text:
Hi!
I have a question regarding the usage of Automa.jl (but not with regards to biology). Is this the right place to ask?

text:
Is it possible / feasible to use Automa to do line by line parsing?

I have a file like this: <https://github.com/SebastianM-C/EPOCHInput.jl/blob/master/test/gauss/input.deck>
and I built a parser manually, but it's slow and buggy. I was wondering if it would be a better idea to switch to Automa

elements.text:
Is it possible / feasible to use Automa to do line by line parsing?

I have a file like this:
and I built a parser manually, but it's slow and buggy. I was wondering if it would be a better idea to switch to Automa

text: I'm asking about line by line parsing since I'm not sure if doing it at the byte level is that human readable / understandable in this case

elements.text: I'm asking about line by line parsing since I'm not sure if doing it at the byte level is that human readable / understandable in this case

text:
Are you saying do it by just defining an FSM on a per-line basis? I think you _could_, but I doubt it would be any better than julia's native string handling.

But you could define a machine that just gives you back blocks that you can deal with in pieces, which might be nicer :shrug:

elements.text: Are you saying do it by just defining an FSM on a per-line basis? I think you
could

, but I doubt it would be any better than julia's native string handling.

But you could define a machine that just gives you back blocks that you can deal with in pieces, which might be nicer

text: I see... My current parser is line by line, but I was also thinking that doing it at the block level would be better

elements.text: I see... My current parser is line by line, but I was also thinking that doing it at the block level would be better

text: I saw a tutorial about Automa.jl, but I'm not sure how to apply it to my case.

elements.text: I saw a tutorial about Automa.jl, but I'm not sure how to apply it to my case.

text:
How are you with regular expressions?

Are your actual files substantially bigger than that example? Building an Automa parser can give you a big speed-up, but it might not be worth it unless IO is really a bottleneck

elements.text:
How are you with regular expressions?

Are your actual files substantially bigger than that example? Building an Automa parser can give you a big speed-up, but it might not be worth it unless IO is really a bottleneck

text: You can use Automa for line-by-line parsing... either you can split up your input into lines and use Automa on each line, that's one possibility. The most effective thing is to use Automa on your whole input and then add an action when you hit a `\n`

elements.text: You can use Automa for line-by-line parsing... either you can split up your input into lines and use Automa on each line, that's one possibility. The most effective thing is to use Automa on your whole input and then add an action when you hit a
\n

text:
I'm familiar with them, but not fluent :))

My actual files are not much bigger that that example. My issue is more with the fact that I would like to be able to use keys defined in a previous block in expressions in the current block

elements.text:

text: Semantically the structure is blocks that contain lines with key-value pairs (there is a possibility to have multi-line expressions if the line ends with a special line-continuation char)

elements.text: Semantically the structure is blocks that contain lines with key-value pairs (there is a possibility to have multi-line expressions if the line ends with a special line-continuation char)

text: You can have any variables hanging around in Automa

elements.text: You can have any variables hanging around in Automa

text: So it might be worth using Automa for the whole file

elements.text: So it might be worth using Automa for the whole file

text:
In this case I'll try to use Automa and ask more when I get stuck

I'm trying to follow the "Tutorial to Automa: Part 1" blogpost and I was wondering if in my case `machine` should describe a block or the whole file

text: You can try with a block first. Automa has very little overhead for starting up. E.g. BioSymbols use Automa to parse three-letter aminoacid strings

elements.text: You can try with a block first. Automa has very little overhead for starting up. E.g. BioSymbols use Automa to parse three-letter aminoacid strings
